Strategic direction shifted so frequently that it was difficult to understand what the company truly wanted to achieve. Department changes, role reshuffling, and reorganizations happened so often that they began to feel like the norm rather than a response to actual business needs. These shifts rarely seemed to solve the challenges employees were facing, and instead added new layers of uncertainty and frustration. A strong push for positivity made it hard to have honest conversations about the impact of all this change. When concerns were raised, the response often emphasized personal resilience rather than addressing the underlying issues causing employee burnout and confusion. Over time, this approach felt more dismissive than supportive. The company talked a lot about growth, but the focus seemed to be on expanding the business rather than building the internal capacity required to support that expansion. In my experience, this led to heavier workloads, diminished work/life balance, and a noticeable strain on the quality of service employees were able to provide. Culturally, there was a clear disconnect between different parts of the organization. Corporate and Property Operations teams didn‚Äôt always feel aligned, and feedback from senior leaders often centered more on optics or messaging than on meaningful improvements to work quality. This created an environment that felt polished on the surface but lacked the genuine support employees needed day-to-day to grow and develop. Leadership frequently spoke about continuous improvement, but the endless cycle of restructuring and shifting priorities made it difficult to see any sustained progress. Instead, it created persistent change fatigue that made it hard to stay motivated or feel invested in the direction of the company. Overall, my time there left me feeling worn down and unsupported. The organization‚Äôs emphasis on rapid movement and financial outcomes seemed to outweigh the need for clarity, stability, and a healthy culture. Ultimately, the environment became too chaotic and discouraging for me to stay.

Perfection and terms like "satisfied" don't exist here and that is not for everyone.

title: To be or not to be? That is the question
pros: You learn a lot how a publicly traded property management company can raise rents and manage a large scale community. Most of the work is done professionally and projects are usually completed in a timely manor. If you work here you will be up to date on how a property management company can run. You get paid vacation, all benefits and bonuses. For some this job can be challenging and long term or just a stepping stone for something better ahead.
cons: Just like other jobs, everyone will have challenges to over come and you will grow if you achieve those challenges. There are some great managers and assistants and there are some bad ones. Bad at managing complaints and how tenants are treated. That's why the online ratings are less than impressive. And also how move outs are treated with charges. We all need extra money, but why not leave with a good impression, rather than over charge them on paint when we can't back it up in court. As a big company you would expect a policy would be the policy. Nope it changes twice a year. Can't make up your mind.

title: Not The Best
pros: Bonuses are pretty good and fair. A lot of holidays off. Useful meetings with closing the office to have the meetings. Company card for emergencies. Online SOP program for quick look up and review, very helpful.
cons: A lot of shady regional managers and area managers. Abuse of power is visible. The CEO doesn‚Äôt care or really know what‚Äôs going on the site level at all. Over worked, under paid, unappreciated, short staffed all over the company but they think nothing is wrong. A lot of changes and additions to software. Our competitors even mention the software overload we have and think it‚Äôs quite funny but for us it‚Äôs embarrassing. Lack of communication across the board in this company. There is no work life balance due to the amount of work and expectations accompanied with our staffing shortages. Regional managers that pretend to listen but may not even have the ability to make changes themselves. I‚Äôm close to certain that the positive reviews are not real or at least written by people in the favorites group.

title: So much demand so little empathy
pros: My review is based on my experience alone. Of course if you meet coworkers that are great they make work easier. So I won‚Äôt include anything like that. The good thing about this job is that it was stable, PTO is good and the discount on rent at their properties is great
cons: They are going through so many changes that they are not stopping to listen to what employees can actually get done, in a reasonable day. Everyone in higher positions is new now and they are so busy trying to prove themselves‚Ä¶that they are overworking everybody under them. Change is good but it has to be a transition it can‚Äôt be full lightening speed ahead.

title: Great company
pros: The essex culture has improved over the years, team work, motivation, employee engagement. I believe they care for their employees and have a passion to assist them reach their goals. I believe if an individual takes the initiative and stays motivated they will assist you to reach your goals. I have been with the company for 5 years, i truly believe its a great company with competitive pay, great benefits.
cons: Not many, i would encourage individuals to maintain a positive perspective as this is a good way to insure a balanced perspective. some feedback for perspective individuals would be ... Essex has a good deal of training, paperwork, and bureaucracy which is the norm in corporate environments. They are very organized and well put together. However they never lose the connection with employees and although they are bigger, they do care. Property management is not easy, however if you have a passion for what you do and want to help people, this is a great place.

title: Sadly declining
pros: Great onsite teams, hard working support departments and good benefits. Technology is getting better. Not much else I can say aside from this.
cons: New leadership is cold and distant. Seems they only care about making their mark and not about the employees. Serious decline in morale since the change. More work less appreciation and a feeling that there is no end in site. Constant fire drills and shifts in strategy. No more empowerment and failure to recognize hard work.

title: Great company with changes all for the better!
pros: Professional and considerate company to work for in the industry. - Amazing benefits including insurance, medical, vision, dental, 401K, EAP mental wellness, career apparel allowance, volunteer time off, wellness day off, and the list goes on. - Exceptional resources are provided to all employees. - Career development. It is an encouraged collaborative environment. - Environmental, social, and Governance conscious company. - Company culture is centered around integrity, mutual respect, passion, transparency, and trust. The company and employees truly live up to the company's expectations. - Work life balance is encouraged. - You will be recognized, rewarded, supported to continue ongoing education. - Customer centric to customers, associates, residents, and investors alike. - Diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging. Overall, I enjoy coming to work and working alongside my coworkers and higher ups. I am looking forward continuing my future with Essex Property Trust. I truly recommend this company to anyone looking to advance their career in the multifamily industry.
cons: I do not have any at this time.

title: They say its getting better
pros: Lots of Locations Friendly staff- co-workers
cons: No one listens, Corporate will come to your property and ask questions and what we need or want. They do nothing. Design team is not friendly, only speaks to management, doesn't acknowledge another staff member. Events are planned because the company "has to " but when you go to them there is no structure, no one cares. Its just something they have to cross off the list of things Essex has to do. They have a employee recognition program that is way to complicated, I don't think it will work. They don't pay employee referrals. Read the fine print, you can show proof but they don't want to pay out. Regionals treat you like the little people. They demand a lot but won't take the time to sit and talk with you. There corporate and your field. At least I can say I can count on my team, other leasers and some other managers but that's as far as it goes. I can't say why I love Essex, wish I could.

title: Endless Opportunities & Career Growth
pros: I have been with Essex since October of 2015. I got hired as Leasing Specialist with no experience in Prop. Management. I was promoted after 1 year to Assistant Manager to a bigger property. I had the privilege of joining the Resident Response Team at Central Services recently. f you work hard and willing to learn, you have endless opportunities to grow your career. Essex will always find a way to provide the resources you need to succeed. Essex is really good at promoting within the company and want to keep hard working employees stay. Feedback from employees are always welcomed and promoted. Everyone I have worked with are amazing people and they cared for me on a personal level.
cons: Working Onsite for 5 years it can get overwhelming. Super fast pace and there's always a lot going on. When you are down by 1 employee, you will have to take in their workload. You may get bombarded with emails and calls/text during your days off. I found it very hard to have a work-life balance specially having 3 kids and full time job.

title: Leasing Specialist
pros: I‚Äôve earned great commission working in the city. There are a few growth opportunities if you put the work in to get promoted. Benefits are comprehensive. My team is fairly cohesive. And the 20% housing discount is extremely helpful.
cons: If you are a Leasing Specialist, you will most likely work every Saturday and Sunday. That‚Äôs just how it goes. My corporate training was unhelpful and made me look unprepared when I arrived on-site as well as affected my performance until I learned everything myself. The package processing systems are insufficient especially for large communities receiving a high volumes of parcels daily. Dress code is unnecessarily restricting.

title: Amazing company to work for
pros: Great people, great hours, wonderful incentives, I am finally working for a company that I feel I fit well with. Getting to know the residents and whatever I can do to make them happy and comfortable is something I really enjoy. Being able to meet great people and make a difference in someone's day is rewarding. Great career path and moving up is something that is available to learn more and achieve goals set. My daughter has worked for the company for several years and so has my son knowing there with a company that allows them and myself to grow is a great feeling as a mother to know your kids are succeeding so I decided to join them and although I have been here a short time I am really enjoying learning the ins and outs of property management it has been a great journey so far I am looking forward to what 2022 brings.
cons: I have not been here long but I don't have any cons

title: Awesome company!
pros: I started with Essex as a Leasing Specialist and worked my way up to be promoted to Assistant Manager with 15 months. I was an Assistant Manager for another 15 months and then was promoted to Community Manager. I've been a Community Manager for just over 2 years now. The potential for growth is amazing. Essex has been continually improving the pathway to career growth with the Training Department. It's great to work for a company that truly values it's employees and I love that they foster a positive company culture. It's about getting the job done efficiently and also about having fun and learning on the way. I really like all the Benefits the company offers!
cons: It would be great to see a larger employee housing discount, and streamlining the Employee Housing process - lots of back & forth paperwork. Some communities are easier to work at, while others can be more challenging -- so definitely research. Sometimes the programs used can be tricky to navigate and little direction from the Corporate office on some changes, so employees are left to guess and figure things out.

title: ESSEX gives employees PTSD.
pros: It's good within the first 60 days. Then you start needing a therapist b/c you don't know if you are coming or going.
cons: *People aren't genuine and quick to backstab each other, Corporate Highschool *Employees are overworked and OT is highly discouraged *Most properties are very short-handed *Company Culture: What can you do for us.. *Constant revolving door with open positions never dropping below 140 (it's a small company) compared to the competitors who hardly have open positions *Zero lack of Upper Management support *Regionals are hardly available b/c they are swamped as well *Procedures change and Regionals wait until the last minute to send changes with expectations to change procedure overnight *Double standards for all employees--1 can do it but you can't *Don't think about voicing your opinion *LOW low pay compared to comps *Company events are lame *ZERO work/life balance (even though they preach it) due to too many open positions

title: Poverty level salaries, all the field employees qualify for section 8 or BMR housing.
pros: Benefits are good. Most properties are above average in comparison to others in a surrounding area.
cons: Training while at work, on site is a joke. Old training module of throwing you in burning house and let you go to work is more accurate. Pay is ridiculous. Housing in the Bay Area is expensive, if you aren't living with mom and dad or your spouse doesn't make 6 figures or you are not living with room mates get ready to sign up for food stamps. Ironic thing is corporate pushes properties to increase annual leases 8-10%, when yearly salary raises are 1%-2%. Employees housing discount is not enough, other properties comp you an apartment. Essex is part of the housing issue in the bay area where rent is unaffordable for a great percentage of the population who work in the service.

title: Best career transition EVER!
pros: I believe Essex has been the best career move for me due to all the Core Values and Behaviors they have to offer. What really stood out to me within the company is the 'Work Life Balance.' I've been in this industry for almost 9 years now and it took me some time to achieve this concept. It really stood out and put that official stamp on things once I arrived at Essex. They really do understand the importance of this and with have two kids this was extremely important to me. Best decision I have made within my career.
cons: I wouldn't really consider this a downside, but there are some changes happening within the company. Although it is a little uneasy to have these changes happen so soon with me joining this company, I am thrilled to see what the future may hold.

title: Great Company, Upper Management Needs Work.
pros: Most of the properties are nice. 401k & Great Benefits. Work and Life Balance is decent. Pay is okay, other property management companies do offer more.
cons: Upper Management (Regionals & Area Managers. LA Region.) Need better communication skills. They never come walk properties. They are completely clueless in communicating new policies with their teams. Also, I have been with the company for almost 2 years, and I have had 2 different regionals in that time frame. Commission! Do not come to this company if you are looking to make a little extra in commissions. Recently a new policy came out. Only leasing consultants will receive renewal commissions. If you are a manager at a building with 200 or more units you will not receive renewal commission. Even though the managers are the ones that approve pricing, generates the letters, posts and mails them. Seriously not fair at all.

title: Great Team and Rewarding Job
pros: Essex allows team members to take care of their customers. Providing housing and great service is a rewarding job over time. They grow the portfolio by building new communities, acquiring them and partnering with other developers. The constant growth allows for career growth for all associates. We have a many communities in each market, so it allows the teams to help each other when they are short staffed. This also allows for promotional opportunites in the same area - Most property Management promotions require you to move because buildings aren't close. Lots of support from Upper Management and a strong culture of collabortaion.
cons: Long-time Upper Management has been turning over (retiring) the past few years, which is a bit scary, but it has all turned out okay so far.

title: Essex Property Trust - What a wonderful place to work
pros: I feel Essex is a wonderful place to work and the people employed here are amazing!!! :) Every holiday is great, especially @ Christmas - we have some of the kindest people working here. Since being employed with Essex the upper management has given me the opportunity to learn and add to my property management knowledge. Essex always has opportunity for growth and the line of communication is always an open door policy. I would recommend this company to family, friends and even when I am in line at a retail store, a bank, or at a restaurant I am always looking to give our business card to people with great customer service skills and the potential to be a great property management employee. This is a company we can trust.
cons: I do not have anything negative to say!!!!

title: Strives to embody company values in all parts of company operations
pros: -Accepts feedback from employee surveys and makes changes accordingly -Promotes from within -Invests in leadership development of employees -Prioritizes work life balance -Encourages transparency from leadership with monthly all company calls led by the CEO and senior leadership.
cons: -Needs more in depth new hire training and more opportunities to take courses to brush up skills

title: Fantastic Company For Women
pros: I never intended to get into property management, yet 3 years later I am still here and it is 100% because Essex is an excellent company to work for. If you apply for a promotion, you will always get an interview even if you aren't quite ready for the position. If you tell your supervisor that you want to grow and learn, they will help you in any way that they can. Every region operates as a team and it is a true joy to work with my colleagues.
cons: Sometimes I wish there were more robust training programs at our disposal, specifically Section 8, BMR, Rent Control training, etc. However, even though there are not many corporate sanctioned training programs in this area - if you ever have any questions, there is always another associate somewhere who is willing and able to help you out.

title: Profit over Employees
pros: Benefits (Healthcare, 401k Match, FSA Plan and Housing Discounts)
cons: * Overworked, underpaid and undervalued. * High Turnover Rate adds additional stress to employees who are already spread thin. * Minimal support from upper management. The support that is received - is often ill-informed and lacks logic. * Unrealistic directives & new policies/procedures are constantly handed down from Corporate employees who have never worked on site - with no regard or input from the on-site team. * 3% Annual Merit increases - even for top performers. Hourly/Salary rates do not keep up with the cost of living nor industry standards. * As of late, "Company culture" is non-existent and only focused on profits and revenue. As a result - employee morale has tanked, causing everyone from Area Managers to Leasing Agents to look for better opportunities.

title: I love working for Essex!
pros: I lived in an Essex community while I was in college and they were hiring for a summer position as a leasing specialist. I got the job and never looked back, even after graduating, I choose to stick with Essex because it is such a great company to work for! There is a lot of opportunity for growth because there are so many properties to move around to. Once you master your position, you can move on to the next opportunity, I like that I never feel stagnant in my career here. I have worked for other property management companies in the past, and comparatively, I like the structure here at Essex much more. I feel like I know what is expected of me and that Essex provides me with the right tools to do my job. Overall, I think this is a great company and I'm happy to work here.
cons: It can be difficult to find coverage, Essex could benefit from an expanded Floating team.

title: Proud to work for Essex
pros: Working for Essex has been a refreshing change. What differentiates Essex from other REITs is their upper management. I've been fortunate to have an amazing Regional Manager who is extremely supportive, who empowers her onsite leaders and is always readily available. The mentality of doing what's best for our residents, makes my job so much easier. It's an amazing feeling not having to say "no" to every resident, and a change from what I had grown accustomed to with previous REITs I have worked for. Essex's approach to residents makes for a more enjoyable work environment.
cons: Lots of different software programs to manage on a daily basis. Often times we are doing repetitive work between one system to another. Our workload could be minimize with a better software system. On a positive note, Essex is working on streamlining the processes and upgrading our software.

title: A Company That Really Cares
pros: I am so very proud of the way Essex has handled the Covid 19 pandemic. They really care about their residents and the community at large. Essex has instituted a very generous care program that will benefit those in need that our employees can participate in to help our tenants and the community. Upper management has done a superb job of keeping employees informed of new developments related to Covid and have been present to answer our questions. They have also done what they can to make it easier to work from home. I can honestly say I have felt 100% supported and I am looking forward to seeing how Essex will continue to serve the community while improving our use of technology to streamline and make all of our processes more efficient.
cons: None come to mind. Essex is definitely going in the right direction!

title: Your Ticket To Growth!
pros: Since I've started with Essex back in 2019 my experience has been nothing but exceptional! From the onboarding advisor program to learning property management onsite, I was given all the tools and resources I needed to succeed. The opportunities are truly endless and the opportunity for growth is unmatched. Employees hard work and dedication does not go unseen which is my favorite aspect so far. Although still fairly new to this profession, I feel like I have decades of experience all thanks to the amazing training and opportunities Essex and the leadership has provided to me. Essex will not disappoint!
cons: Wage does not match living expenses but you qualify for a 20-40% monthly discount on rent with the employee housing program.

title: Positive and Supportive Culture
pros: I‚Äôve worked for Essex for over 10 years and have seen the growth and change that has positively impacted the employees and residents directly. Although it‚Äôs a large company, it still feels like your voice is heard and you are acknowledged for your hard work and contributions. During the pandemic, I was so proud and relieved to work at Essex, as I saw many of my peers that worked for other competitors being laid off. Essex ensured employees did not lose their jobs, that we were supported, created new positions, and provided a multitude of resources not only for us but our residents.
cons: No company is perfect and luckily I don't work for a company that expects perfection. I don't have any cons at this time.

title: Happy Camper
pros: I have been in the multi family industry for approx. 17 years. Worked for ASN and AVB in the past. Essex is on par with those other two and excels in some areas over both. I am valued, respected, well compensated and I am able to do my job with minimal red tape. I work with some very talented people and value these relationships. I feel as if I have found my home. When ASN was bought out I did not know if I was going to find that again. I hope to be with Essex until I am ready to retire.
cons: I have do not have any negative comments.

title: A True Leader in the Property Management Industry
pros: Regional managers are supportive, available and invested. However, Community Managers are really entrusted with running the properties and overseeing daily operations. Essex employees are a cut above the rest--committed, driven, energetic and productive. Training and technology make so many things more accessible and really help set associates up for success. Community is really promoted between properties and everyone is eager to be helpful and is committed to the overall success of the company. Benefits are also great!
cons: Only real con is not having housing allowances. The employee housing program is not completely employee oriented and can be difficult to navigate.

title: They Hear their Associates
pros: Open door communication with RPM. Great benefits that increase over length of employment. You feel valued and supported by the organization. The support departments are very helpful even if in CA. You are encouraged to facilitate your team to succeed individually and as a team.
cons: Hard to advance from CM. Not a clear pathway to see growth beyond CM.

title: Amazing Place to Work
pros: Working for Essex has been amazing. This is a company that values their employees, treats them fairly, encourages them to continue to learn, but also provides the resources to make it possible. Before working for Essex I did not have work life balance. And now I do have the balance that I needed, and Essex understands the importance of it. The hybrid model is excellent. Management is very knowledgeable and does their best to transfer that knowledge to their employees. Essex is such a great place to work. Everyone's opinion matters, and it doesn't matter what your position is. All ideas are welcome and the team player environment/collaboration has to be unmatched in the industry, and I'm sure amongst many many industries, and honestly probably all. I am very grateful to be a part of the Essex team and am looking forward to my future with the company.
cons: There really isn't any cons.

title: Assistant Community Manager
pros: There are things that Essex offers that can be beneficial and if you have a secondary source of income. Opportunity for commission Housing discount Decent benefits
cons: Essex upper management does not care, nor does HR. Beware of who you work for when you are onsite at a property. Community managers will never be at the property and leave the assistants and leasing consultants to do the MAJORITY of the work. This has happened at multiple properties. Advancement is nonexistent unless you know someone who is willing to help, not based on merit at all. Also if you think you will get a vacation without a hassle, think again. Never bring concerns to HR, that just allows the rumors to fly and makes the problem worse.

title: Research first, then submit application
pros: Broad understanding of the housing market in the bay area region
cons: Work/life balance is #1 priority for stabilized properties that was thrown out the window, ability to provide advancement opportunities for those who exemplified commitment to the company, middle management lacking connection and exposure to on-site properties- unacceptable, disconnection of on-site and corporate office, you are a number (don't lose hindsight of YOUR most valued asset to the company)

title: Has potential, absolutely a dumpster fire right now.
pros: Clear direction and goals for the company itself, fairly decent benefits package, and a clear desire to improve
cons: The top brass don‚Äôt listen to the operations team. The corporate environment is a toxic ‚Äúthe company‚Äôs needs come first‚Äù sludge heap, a good 25% of the company has either already quit or is on their two weeks or are being phased out due to recent structural changes. No one knows what‚Äôs going on, half your managers are sleeping with each other and the other half or crying in their offices at random intervals of the day.

title: Give alot, get a little
pros: - Growing company - Stocks value over $200 per share - Merged with BRE - PTO - Full time positions - Benefits
cons: -High turn over -Low pay/income cap -No holiday bonus / quarterly or yearly bonuses -Vacation/time off requests are usually denied or the manager guilts you for even requesting it during the spring-fall season because it's too 'BUSY' -No work/life balance -If you have children, working in this industry makes it difficult to take time off to spend with them- unless you're a property manager or work in the corporate office then you come and go as you please -Expensive benefits package -Holiday function was horrific. Compare NorCal's holiday events to ours and it's like comparing a five star restaurant to Denny's.

title: Growth within Essex
pros: Essex overall has been a great company to be a part of. The Company offers housing discounts as well as 401k Medical, Dental, Vision, etc. I have been with this company for 5 years now and plan to continue to grow. I started off as a Leasing Specialist for about 3 years then got promoted to an Assistant Manager for about 1 year then received another promotion shortly afterwards, to a Sr. Assistant Manager which I stayed as for about 2 and a half years. As of 12/6/2021 I received another promotion and am now currently part of our Corporate Office and could not be more thankful for the opportunity to be a part of this company.
cons: Unfortunately due to Covid Essex has not been able to throw any events like my all time favorite Holiday Event, but they have been making all employees feel special by providing us with a week of different awards.

title: Large Corporation doing it right
pros: Upper management that truly cares about the people and the residents. Competitive pay, full benefits, great working conditions.
cons: tantly striving to improve and help employees grow and succeed in their positions. They have kept a good balance between large corporation and mom and pop culture.

title: Lots of Opportunity
pros: I have worked with Essex for seven years and have been able to make connections across the company, which has lead to the opportunity to take a new position and learn a completely new aspect of the business for me. Essex really encourages the growth of their associates and promotes from within whenever possible. There's a focus on making the company one their associates want to stay with, from benefits options, perks and business operations updates. Essex wants their associates to love what they do.
cons: I'm currently in one of the smaller regions of the company and have felt slightly limited in the past, due to not having a large presence of many departments. I feel the mindset is shifting, so that associates don't necessarily have to be in the same region as their department to work efficiently. I look forward to continued shifts like this providing flexibility and opportunity to associates.

title: Great Company!
pros: I have been working at Essex for a little over a year now and couldn't ask for a better place to work. I really enjoy working with my team. I have a great manager who truly cares. Essex cares and values their associates. They go above and beyond to address the concerns of their associates and make the needed changes to accommodate all. They genuinely embrace diversity and culture. They have various associate appreciation events. They have great benefits, competitive pay, bonuses and other amazing incentives. They offer a great work/life balance which is very important, especially in this day and age. I have never worked for a company before that goes so above and beyond to show how much they truly appreciate their associates.
cons: I don't have any cons to speak of.

title: Compensation Not Based On Merit
pros: Very talented co-workers, communities in desirable locations.
cons: Even after recent pay range restructure Essex is behind in employee compensation. Experienced Community Managers will look elsewhere to find fair compensation. Annual increases are not inline with manager and asset performance. Internal systems are still archaic and clunky. There has been considerate effort to improve these problems, but Essex still does not meet the mark. With a very competitive recrutment culture we are currently in Essex in the PNW continues to lose great people to other companies while hanging on to difficult, under-performing middle management. I am actively considering offers from other companies after a disappointing 3 years with Essex.

title: Great Company to Work for.
pros: Company CARES about you and gives you the necessary tools to SUCCED your GOALS and prepares you for growth within the company. Great Benefits from Health, Vision, Dental, 401k, Retirement, Vitality, Employee Discounts, etc. Awesome locations and great support from upper management.
cons: I cant find anything wrong with Essex. Their are a lot of other competitors out there, we are keeping up with the changing times and trying to balance our employees health and wellness at the same time. That gets tricky at some points because things are constantly changing.

title: Enjoyed the pay, work/life balance can get out of balance depending on support system
pros: pay/benefits housing discounts room for career growth
cons: uniform intense and fast-paced offices that require lots of people for smooth work flows, this is hard when employee turnover is very high and not enough support from leadership

title: Amazing place to work! Couldn't be happier
pros: I love working for Essex. In my first 30 days, I can tell you they have great people, they value life/work balance, they are inclusive and everything they do is with the associates in mind. It feels like a family, building relationships is something the company values. They are progressive and very advanced with the technology they use. I am excited for the future of work at Essex. Additionally, I am super excited about the DEI progress the company is making by appointing a female CEO next year.
cons: I can't think of anything because I have only had pleasant experiences here. I feel like I belong here. Everyone has been so welcoming and it's a fun place to work.

title: Poor Regional Management
pros: Some properties have recent renovations in good locations.
cons: Management. The Pacific Northwest Region is troubled. Management is disconnected from the frontline workers and was not interested in reports about daily traffic and other activities at the property. Allowed poor leadership run unchecked until everyone gave notice to leave. A culture of fear and hostility between management and staff.

title: Bittersweet
pros: The team I worked with were AMAZING! We are all still friends even though none of them still work for the company. I met some amazing people who lived at the property whom I‚Äôm still friends with. The community manager whom hired me left a sweet spot in my heart. I gained experience in the property management field. Great benefits beside the rent discount on market rate units. Monthly commissions for lease renewals $60-$320.
cons: - Listen to your employees when they report issues. - HR needs to provide better support to employees - TURN OVER TURN OVER - Select better community managers, pick someone who will represent the company in the BEST light.

title: Okay company to work for but everyone is just waiting for a better opportunity somewhere else
pros: Friendly group of people to work with is the saving grace of Essex
cons: Managers are often promoted from outside the company and have no idea how to do their job resulting in months of under-appreciated training from their assistant managers who are repeatedly overlooked for advancement opportunities. Regionals and Community Managers hire their friends rather than who deserves it. Pay and benefits also aren‚Äôt as good as other PM companies. Housing benefit only covers 20% of rent. You might as well be on the clock 24/7, even on off days you‚Äôll get calls and questions.

title: Run as far as possible
pros: most of the pros in the company aren't really there any more. after the pandemic this company is squeezing really hard to save in all areas
cons: My experience here was disappointing to say the least. The overtime for the on calls only get paid in double time up to the time you were working,not the full two hours. The offices are closed so all on-site support falls on maintenance and porters. Management is always pushing to do more than possible in return for a review with a higher score,but won't actually do it. Company does offer opportunities to get certifications and training classes but depending who your manager will be,you will most likely not get a raise. Most buildings only have 1 tech and 1 porter on site and no supervisor,or 1 supervisor 1 porter no tech

title: Great to be part of the E-Team!
pros: If you are looking for an established company to grow your career with, friendly and knowledgeable people to work with, and an excellent company culture, Essex Property Trust is a great place! - They really care about your professional and career development. -The company culture is excellent with a robust fitness and wellness program and fun employee appreciation events such as birthday celebrations, a summer picnic and community-based service events. - What I appreciate the most is the sense of belonging to a team that is committed to Essex's mission statement and core values of integrity, fairness, accountability, and unwavering urgency.

title: Highly recommend company to work

title: The Essex Culture
pros: I LOVE OUR CEO-He is the sweetest man on earth...if he sees your hands full trying to open the door, he'll hold the door for you with a smile and he and actually knows my name! He acknowledges your presence and is just overall amazing. I love my team and their spunky energy. The office is beautiful, well maintained, with great vendors to be there on the spot when you request them. There's coffee bars in every corner to keep you going throughout the day, they'll even stock the ladies room with feminine napkins. There's refrigerators to store your lunch, microwaves, and toaster ovens too. Friendly & Genuine staff, for the most part. Everyone is your friend wherever you turn. Everyone loves everyone (at least that's what it mostly feels like). We are a family. Easy going vibe. Sometimes you'll see an executive in their gym clothes with a handful paperwork, so you know it's a health inspired environment. Did I mention, there's also a little gym as an added amenity to burn off that extra energy on your break or lunch? There's even a mommy room too! There are copy rooms in each area so work flow maintains a steady pace. If you seek help, everyone always extends a helping hand so you'll never fall behind. There's a strong support in team effort on that part. You will NEVER get a cold shoulder turned on you. There's an open door policy, so you can literally walk up to your executive, director, or manager for anything. I have a strong support from my direct manager also, she's terrific and I love her so much. Paid Holidays and Benefits are a plus. There's monthly events that bring the team together, so that's nice also. There is a cash perk for recruiting friends. You get commission if you work onsite. Company major gatherings are held a couple times a year, so that's nice also for mingling and building your network. I love my job. I love my job-I LOVE MY JOB! I have made the best of friends here and enjoy working with them and being in their presence. I actually go to work, SO excited to go.
cons: Dental plan is really bad...but you can choose between Kaiser or your own health provider. While considerably our apartments are the best in the market, the customer care turnaround response time is quite terrible to be honest. People these days are not patient to wait 48 hours until their questions are answered, where they expect an answer right then and there...and that isn't the case here. We forward them to an automated voicemail system...which is unheard of in the customer service industry alone. You can call anywhere and at least someone will pickup the phone and help you, you may be transferred a gazillion times, but at least you'll be transferred to a live person. We're a lot slower to progression than most companies out there so expect a delay when you want something done to help the company expand and grow, or even if you're expecting a review for something such as a raise and for that to actually take place or happen at all. You want a raise? Expect a year and a half for it to keep being pushed out because they're "too busy" to consider your request to really embark in your career. It doesn't matter how much you love it here, or what position you're in. That's just the sad truth. Know your market before coming in and be ready for .......an......extended..........delay.......to your requests, whatever it may be. It's not about what you know-but who you know. HR has a big pull from Executives, so if you have an issue with them, or their admin below them... expect that they will not get written up for their hostility towards you and they will literally get away with anything no matter how bad. It will be brushed off as if nothing happened, not even a warning or write-up. It's the nature here, so the best thing is to stay to yourself and bite your tongue when a snarky remark or comment is thrown at you. Speak up in confidentiality, it won't stay confidential, and whoever you speak up about will find out somehow, retaliate against you and make your life a living hell...and of course, get away with it while they're at it. Quit...and you let them win. Will it get better if you leave? No, because that horrible person will still be there...just because of WHO they are representing and working directly under. And you can't choose not to work with them nor can you avoid them either because they'll find a way to get in the mix of YOUR job too. Yes hostility exists here and there is no practice of justice for it, that's how weak our HR system is. Think of it as a mirage. That's what it can feel like at times. You just have to make the best of it on your own. I probably made this sound like a terrible place to work, and I'm sorry if you're considering a position here. In honesty, it is a great place and environment, just certain people can make it extremely difficult. So if it happens to you, that you're the chosen one to be bullied, know that you're not alone and you're not a pushover-It's everywhere, I presume. And though write-ups aren't quite a thing here and there actually is a high tolerance for promoting bad behavior (even though when you sign your contract it says there's a zero tolerance for it), you are actually supported from your direct manager...and they will lookout for your general well-being...even speak up on your behalf. So there's that. Is that the greatest solution? No. But it does help ease the tension to have a friend on your side and actually be your manager. It can be cut throat, because EVERYONE is passionate about their job and position they hold, so there will be butting heads, a lot actually, but if you are mentally strong and don't let harsh words hurt you or bring you down, you'll succeed and get ahead. Call it a love-hate relationship. Where you hate the people you work with (of course not everyone) so much that you love them because in the end, you realize we're all family. We don't just work with each other...you spend an entire day with each other spending more time with colleagues moreso your actual real family at home. So yes, the reality hits the fan from time to time. You've got to decide how you're going to take it and handle it and choose if this is the place that's for you. If it is-great. More power to you coming in to know what to expect. If not, don't worry-It's not for everyone, just putting it out there to give you a perspective of the real work environment at ESSEX.

title: We Feel Undervalued
pros: Essex will provide all the tools necessary to be successful. There are a few Managers within the company that genuinely will promote growth and development, though I will not confidently expressed this as consistent throughout each team. There are various opportunities for growth, and the housing program will provide some alleviation to the financial burden. However, in some counties, the discounts could be more appropriate.
cons: Essex will say they value those who take initiative and become an asset to the company. Though when massive, company-wide changes occur, there is no transparency, nor consideration. Proximity and politics play a role in advancement amongst some teams and when challenging the valuation of one's own contributions in regards to roles and compensation, no consideration is made beyond the cost benefit analysis, not event that initiative we spoke of. Sometimes it feels like the company is harder on employees and less inclined to work with them as opposed to residents. Work your tail off if you would like, but better know someone with decision making power.

title: You Get What You Give
pros: I have worked in the industry for over 12 years and have spent half of my years with Essex. I have had ample opportunities to grow within the organization and have been able to actively contribute to the company. Essex looks for "can do attitude" people who are willing to communicate issues, ideas and ways of improving our overall business. One thing that really attracted me to the company was the tenure of the leadership team and various employees throughout the organization. The company makes you feel like you are an investment rather than a number or job title. The more you invest, by way of effort, in the company the more they invest in you. The property manager, regional managers and division leaders are really committed to improving the way we do our business. And we are growing! Many of our corporate departments have added support to improve things. So glad to see better systems in place as when I started we were on a DOS based computer system, little marketing support, no classes and little capital and maintenance support. Now that has all changed. And for the better. Before we were expected to do it all on our own and now there are support systems/departments in place.
cons: Anyone and everyone who is going to reflect on a company will have things they would like to see different. I'll let my supervisor know what we can improve on.

title: Take the good with the bad
pros: Advance quickly if you show that you're capable Many communities in close proximity
cons: Essex expects employees to know their residents very well but they transfer them from property to property so frequently that it's nearly impossible. Managers are expected to know their properties and residents but they don't trust on our opinions on what will make our residents happy and retain them. They generally see their residents as money instead of people and at times they make decisions that anger the residents, but expect us to take responsibility and act as though they were our decisions. The majority of my residents don't think that Essex is a very moral company, and they tell me so frequently.

title: I learned a lot: good and bad.
pros: - Training is spectacular: I will always use some of the things I learned in training classes. - I loved most aspects of my job from seeing new apartments, remodels, learning about budgets, renting units, how to sell. - Most of the employees are awesome. - Decent pay if you're good at your job and renting. - Discounted rent if you live on an Essex Property.
cons: - Raising rents in huge amounts to residents is hard, especially with great tenants. - Management promotes the worst possible employees then wonders where they went wrong. - Understaffed offices. - Long hours, weekends. - Only really have holiday parties. Minimal perks.

title: Making a career
pros: I have worked for Essex for nearly 7 years and have been through my fair share of ups and downs with the company. I absolutely admire the way our company handles the tough times. Essex keeps an employee and resident focus while maintaining a high level of professionalism and business sense. The company has developed a DEI program that involves representatives from all levels of the organization. The pay, and benefits are comparable and our 401k match is phenomenal.
